div.p: Anxiety is not a bad thing.
Some level of anxiety helps to boost performance.
It's when anxiety interferes with the ability to function that it needs to be addressed.
And, we all know how that feels: an overwhelming sense of dread, a rapid heartbeat,
excessive perspiration, inability to focus.
Students often complain of anxiety at the thought of taking exams...test anxiety.
That's not a good time to experience an inability to focus
or an overwhelming sense of dread.
So, how do we overcome test anxiety?
Honestly, overcoming is probably not the right word.
Managing is probably a more realistic expectation.
And, since it does enhance performance, maintaining some level
of anxiety is actually beneficial.
A major step to managing test anxiety is through preparation.
If you're prepared for an exam, you're less likely to stress over it.
Preparation takes place throughout the session or semester
and culminates with a review of the material.
It does not mean cramming for an exam.
Cramming doesn't work.
It often takes away from time spent resting or eating,
two things that aid in optimum performance.
Get plenty of sleep the evening before an exam and make certain you've eaten,
at least a snack, before the exam.
When sitting for the exam, don't start the exam until you've carefully read the directions.
It would a terrible waste of time and brain power if you answered all of the essay questions
when the directions said to choose only one.
Wasting time is something you definitely don't want to do.
If you don't know the answer to a question, skip that one to return to later.
Something in the rest of the exam may help answer that question.
And dwelling on a question too long creates frustration,
which can make you feel more anxious.
A good way to stay focused on essay questions is to write a quick outline.
This will get theories, concepts, etc. on paper allowing you to focus on the writing
and assuring that you won't forget a point while putting together the essay response.
Pay attention to your writing.
Keep it concise.
It's true...first responses are usually correct.
Try not to second guess yourself.
If you are really torn between answers, select the one you believe to be best
or answer the question to the best of your ability at that point.
Put a question mark in the margin and return to it later, time permitting.
Don't read into questions.
Take them at face value.
Don't start saying things like, "True...but."
After going through the exam, time permitting...return to the items
with question marks in the margin.
Don't spend too much time...make changes for anything you feel strongly about.
Just remember the first response adage.
Now go to those questions you didn't answer.
Do your best to select an answer.
Unless otherwise noted, any answer...in that situation...will be better than no answer.
Still have time?
Double check your work.
If you have used a "bubble sheet" for your responses,
try to make certain you've placed the answers in the correct spaces
and that you aren't one question off as that will make all subsequent answers incorrect.
Don't worry about who has finished the test and in how much time.
Just because someone finishes an exam in what seems
to be record time doesn't mean they have aced the exam.
It's just as likely they were clueless and raced
through the exam just to finish and leave the room.
Finally, don't dwell on the exam after you leave the room.
No racing to check your notes to see how you think you did.
It's over and it's time to prepare for the next class.
